Fig. 1 N2 isothermal adsorption-desorption profiles of prepared MoS2 catalysts from different hydrothermal times. Fig 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of MoS2 catalysts at different hydrothermal times: (a) before reaction; (b) after reaction for 1 h; (c) after reaction for 1.5 h; (d) after reaction for 20 h. Fig 2 Fig. 3 HRTEM images of the spent catalysts under different hydrothermal times: (a) 6 h; (b) 12 h; (c) 18 h; (d) 24 h. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Raman spectra of catalysts under different hydrothermal times. Fig 4 Fig. 5 TG-DTG profiles of MoS2 catalysts prepared at different times: (a) before reaction and (b) after reaction. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Activities of Mo-based catalysts prepared in different hydrothermal times. Fig 6 Fig. 7 XRD patterns of MoS2 catalysts with different hydrothermal pH values: (a) before reaction; (b) after reaction for 1 h; (c) after reaction for 1.5 h; (d) after reaction for 20 h. A simple one-step hydrothermal synthesis was developed to modulate the stability of MoS2 for catalytic sulfur-resistant methanation. The methanation performance was optimized by tuning hydrothermal time and solution pH value. The catalysts were characterized by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET), X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Raman spectroscopy and thermogravimetric and derivative thermogravimetric (TG/DTG) analysis. It was found that both extended hydrothermal time and weak acidic solution value was benefit to prepare the MoS2 catalyst with high stacking layers. TG/DTG analysis indicated that no obvious coke deposition occurred in the MoS2 catalysts during methanation reaction. Moreover, density functional theory (DFT) simulation result proved that with the increase of stacking layers, the electron density between Mo atoms and their neighbor S atoms was strengthened and the interlayer interaction was enhanced. Therefore, the MoS2 catalysts with high stacking layers was stable since they were not easily deactivated by sintering or substitution of active S atoms by O atoms during the reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords MoS2 Stacking layers Interlayer interaction Deactivation 1 Introduction In the past few years, global energy crisis and environmental protection issues have gradually paid attention [1,2]. Energy is an important material basis for human survival and social and economic development [3]. Thus, it is urgent to develop clean and efficient energy technologies [4]. Natural gas as a high combustion efficiency, clean, safety and free of pollutants fuel has gained increasing attention in the word [5]. However, as demand for natural gas increases year by year, supply shortages begin to appear [6]. Then, coal-to-natural gas technology, which uses coal as raw material, comes into being, effectively alleviating the demand gap [7]. During this process, synthetic natural gas (SNG) can be manufactured via coal gasification and subsequent methanation, among which the catalytic syngas to methane is the critical process [6]. Both noble metal-based catalysts (Ru [8,9], Rh [10,11] and Pt [12]) and non-noble metal-based catalysts (MoS2 [13,14] and Ni [15,16]) have been studied to be promising candidates for methanation reaction. Ni-based catalysts performances high CO conversion and excellent CH4 selectivity regarded as the typical methanation catalysts. However, the sensitivity of Ni-Based catalysts to sulfur poisoning and strict requirements for H2/CO ratio (≥3) hinder its application prospects in sulfur-resistant methanation reactions [17]. MoS2 catalysts catches researchers’ attention due to its high activity in water-gas shift (WGS) reaction and sulfur-resistant capability [18]. It was reported that the non-supported MoS2 catalysts by hydrothermal showed significant sulfur-resistant methanation activity [13]. Especially, the methanation activity of this kind of MoS2 catalyst increased monotonously as the hydrothermal temperature decreased from 180 °C to 150 °C in the process of low-temperature hydrothermal synthesis. Characterization results revealed that with the decrease of hydrothermal temperature, the content of bridging s 2 2 − in MoS2 catalysts increased while the S-S bond in s 2 2 − could dissociate H2 more efficiently [19] and subsequently formed -SH functional group. Moreover, the active hydrogen generated from S-S ligands would migrate on the catalyst surface and form -SH group that would promote H2 adsorption and dissociation [20]. It was reasonable to believe that further decreasing the hydrothermal temperature to 140 °C would get improved methanation activity, which needed to be proved by experiment. As expected, the initial activity of the MoS2 catalyst prepared by hydrothermal at 140 °C was further increased decreased but the it decreased about 20% after 20 h reaction, which indicated that the stability became worse with decreased hydrothermal temperature to 140 °C. Stability is the key factor in the industrial application, so it is important to improve the stability on the premise of ensuring the activity of the catalysts. Meanwhile, carbon deposition and loss of active S are the main reasons for MoS2 deactivation in hydrofining [21], oil desulfurization [22], sour water-gas shift reactions [23]. Wang et al. [21] reported that three causes were showed in the deactivation of the supported CoMo catalyst: by-product water, loss of sulfur and coke deposition during the hydrotreating of waste cooking oil (WCO) to produce fuels process. In order to enhance the stability of CoMo catalyst, in situ drying, resulfiding the spent catalysts and avoiding high temperature operation were carried out. Although the stability was enhanced efficiently, its operating costs increased significantly. Rana et al. [23] reported that the catalysts with wider pore size distribution and pore volume were less likely to be blocked by coke during heavy oil hydrogenation, thus ensuring catalysts stability. Furthermore, improving the anchoring capability of the support on the active metal and enhancing the diffusion and transfer of the products on the surface may effectively reduce the possibility of coke formation and Mo aggregation of the catalyst, so as to improve the stability of catalysts. In this paper, a series of MoS2 catalysts were prepared by hydrothermal with different times and pH values at 140 °C. A series of characterizations were employed to examine the structure and physicochemical properties of the obtained MoS2. The relationship between the number of stacking layers of MoS2 and the sulfur-resistant methanation performance was explored. DFT study was used to investigate the effect of stacking layer number on the interaction between layers and stability of catalysts. 2 Experiment 2.1 Catalysts preparation The chemical reagents used were analytical purity and no further purification was required. MoS2 catalyst was synthesized by hydrothermal method. During the synthesis, ammonium heptamolybdate (2 mmol (NH4)6Mo7O24•4H2O) and thiourea (84 mmol) were dissolved in distilled water (65 mL) and vigorously stirred for 45 min to generate a uniform solution. Subsequently, the solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, and the temperature was maintained at 140 °C for 6, 12, 18 and 24 h, respectively. When the autoclave was naturally cooling down to room temperature, black precipitates were collected by centrifugation and washed with distilled water and absolute ethanol for three times, respectively. Finally, the obtained product was dried at 70 °C overnight under vacuum conditions. The catalysts were denoted as Cat-X (X represented the hydrothermal time, corresponding the value range is 6, 12, 18 and 24) and the fresh catalysts were denoted as Cat-X-A, the spent catalysts were denoted as Cat-X-B. The MoS2 catalysts with different pH values were prepared. The weighted oxalic acid was dissolved in deionized water to prepare a solution with C(H2C2O4) concentration 3 mol/L. Ammonium heptamolybdate (9.92 g (NH4)6Mo7O24•4H2O) and thiourea (25.68 g) were dissolved in distilled water (220 mL) and vigorously stirred at 200 RPM for 45 min to generate a homogeneous blue solution A. The oxalic acid solution was slowly added to the solution A with about 1 drop per 3 s at room temperature, and then stirred at 200 RPM for 24 h. Then the piston of the funnel was closed and left to set for 5 min to measure the pH value. If the solution pH did not reach the desired value, continue adding oxalic acid solution until the pH value was 1, 3 or 0.5. Continued stirring at 200 RPM for 10 min before closing the stirring. Then the solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and maintained the temperature at 140 °C for 24 h. After the autoclave was naturally cooled down to room temperature, black precipitates were collected by centrifugation and washed with distilled water and absolute ethanol for three times, respectively. Finally, the obtained product was dried at 70 °C overnight under vacuum conditions. The catalysts were denoted as Cat-PX (X represented the solution pH value, which is 1, 3 or 0.5). In addition, the pH value was 5.3 without oxalic acid added and the corresponding catalyst was regarded as Cat-P5.3. 2.2 Catalyst characterization In order to characterize the textural properties of catalysts, the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured on a Micromeritics Tristar-3000 instrument. The specific surface areas were exhibited from adsorption-desorption isotherms by the multi-point Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Before measurements, the sample was vacuumed first at 90 °C for 1 h and subsequently at 300 °C for 3 h. The X‐ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of catalysts were performed using a Rigaku D/max 2500 v/pc X‐ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) with CuKα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) from 10° to 80° with the scanning rate of 5°/min. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and EDX-mapping were characterized by JEM F200, which was fabricated by the JEOL company. The TEM images were taken at the work voltage 200 kV. Prior to measurement, the catalyst powder was dispersed in ethanol, subsequently a few drops of suspension deposited onto a lacey carbon film supported on a Cu grid. The sample was then transferred in a stream of N2 to a sample holder attached to the microscope. The CHNS/O elemental analysis was conduct with an elemental analyzer (Elementar vario MICRO cube). To guarantee the accuracy of the results, each sample was measured three times, with the average values used in this study. Laser Raman spectra of samples were obtained using an InViaReflex (Renishaw, England) spectrometer (He-Ne laser). The excitation wave-number at 532 nm with an Ar+-ion laser was employed as the incident light beam. The laser beam intensity and the spectrum slit width were 8 mW and 25 μm, respectively. The deposited carbon on the spent catalysts was determined by TGA STA449F3. During testing, measured about 6 mg samples heated from room temperature to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min in the air atmosphere, and the weight change was recorded to obtained the TG curve. In situ Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) analysis of NO adsorption on MoS2 was conducted on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet 6700 spectrometer with an MCT/A detector and a vacuum system. The sample (25 mg) was pressed to a disk-shaped pellet and placed in the in-situ transmission IR cell. The sample was pretreated at 400 °C for 0.5 h in 30 mL/min He and cooled to room temperature. Then, it was exposed to 5% NO/He at 30 °C until saturated. Prior to the measurement, evacuation was conducted to remove the NO molecules in the gas phase and those that were weakly adsorbed on the samples. 2.3 Computational simulation methods The density functional theory (DFT) was performed using the Vienna AB into Simulation Package (VASP) and carried with the projector augmented wave (PAW) approach [24]. The plane-wave based spin-polarized were described with the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [25]. A cutoff energy of 400 eV was used and the a Monkhorst-Pack mesh with a grid of 3 × 3 × 3 and 3 × 3 × 2 corresponding to two layers model and three layers model [26,27]. And the total energy was converged to lower than 1.0 × 10−6 eV/atom and the maximum force on all unconstrained atoms were less than 0.02 eV/Å. As for the lamellar structure model was built to 3 × 3 × 1. 2.4 Catalytic evaluation The sulfur-resistant methanation was measured in a continuous-flow fixed-bed tubular reactor (i.d. =8 mm) at the condition of 450 °C and 3.0 MPa. The detailed information about the experimental facility has been described in our previous research [28]. A catalyst of 3 g (20–40 mesh) was located in the middle part of the stainless-steel tubular reactor. The feeding gasses (WHSV = 5000 mL/(h•g cat) composition was 49.7 vol% H2, 50.0 vol% CO and 0.3 vol% H2S. The water generated during the reaction was condensed by a cold trap, meanwhile the outlet gasses were analyzed qualitatively online with GC system equipped with a set of thermal conductive detector (TCD) and a set of flame ionized detector (FID). The CO conversion, product hydrocarbon selectivity, and carbon balance were shown as follows: (1) X CO = n ( CO , in ) − n ( CO , out ) n ( CO , in ) × 100 % (2) S C H 4 = n ( C H 4 , out ) n ( C H 4 , out ) + n ( C 2 H 6 , out ) + n ( C 3 + , out ) × 100 % (3) S C 2 H 6 = n ( C 2 H 6 , out ) n ( C H 4 , out ) + n ( C 2 H 6 , out ) + n ( C 3 + , out ) × 100 % (4) S C 3 + = n ( C 3 + , out ) n ( C H 4 , out ) + n ( C 2 H 6 , out ) + n ( C 3 + , out ) × 100 % (5) C B = 1 − [ 1 − n ( CO , out ) + n ( C O 2 , out ) + n ( C H 4 , out ) + n ( C 2 H 6 , out ) + n ( C 3 + , out ) n ( CO , in ) ] × 100 % where XCO represents the CO conversion, Sj (SCH4, SC2H6, and S3+) refers to the hydrocarbon selectivity for the products (CH4, C2H6, and C3+), n represents molar flowrate and the sub-scripts “in” and “out” refer to the inlet and outlet gas streams, respectively. To make sure the reliability of the activity data, carbon balance C B was calculated that was within ±3%. The composition of the gas products after reaction was analyzed online by a gas chromatographic analyzer SP3420A equipped with one thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and one hydrogen flame ionization detector (FID). For the TCD, H2 was used as carrier gas using the packed column with TDX-01 (outer diameter of 3 mm and length of 1 m) to quantitatively analyze CO, CO2 and CH4. For the FID, the KB-Al2O3/Na2SO4 capillary column with an inner diameter of 0.32 mm and length of 50 m was used to analyze CH4, C2H6 and C3+ hydrocarbons. The carrier gas flow rate of TCD is 30 mL/min, while the column temperature, detector and injector temperature are 100 °C, and the outlet gas products entered the SP3420A for online analysis. For TCD detector, the content of CO, CH4 and CO2 by TCD was obtained by external standard method. Calibration curves of each component are determined by introducing mixed gasses at different compositions, and the simulated formula are shown as follows: (6) Q CO = 1 . 064 × 1 0 − 7 × A CO + 3 . 243 × 1 0 − 3 (7) Q C H 4 = 1 . 311 × 1 0 − 7 × A C H 4 − 7 . 444 × 1 0 − 3 (8) Q C O 2 = 9 . 673 × 1 0 − 8 × A C O 2 + 4 . 607 × 1 0 − 3 Where Q represents the molar fraction, and A represents the peak area from TCD signals. The content of C2H6 and C3H8 was obtained by using CH4 as the internal gas. The calibration mole factor of C2H6 to CH4 is 0.4735, while the calibration factor of C3H8 to CH4 is 0.3701. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The influence of hydrothermal synthesis time for catalyst 3.1.1 N2-pysisorption analysis Textural properties of the catalysts hydrothermal synthesis at 140 °C based on the N2 adsorption-desorption were evaluated in Fig. 1 and the specific surface areas of the obtained catalysts were determined by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method as shown in Table 1 . It was illustrated that all the catalysts presented typical Ⅱ with H4 hysteresis loops according to the classification of IUPAC Technical Report [29], confirming the existence of mesoporous structure. Before methanation reaction, the specific surface area of Cat-12-A was 46 m2/g, higher than other catalysts. While the Cat-6-A obtained the lowest specific surface area. What's more, after methanation reaction, the Cat-12-B, Cat-18-B and Cat-24-B showed the similarly specific surface area and pore volume, indicating that during the reaction, the catalyst continued to grow and the final crystallization degree tended to be the same, thus showing similar specific surface area and pore volume. However, the Cat-6-B showed the different results, that may due to too short hydrothermal synthesis time resulting in crystal immaturity. 3.1.2 XRD results The XRD patterns of the catalysts prepared at different hydrothermal times at 140 °C were shown in Fig. 2 . As shown in Fig. 2(a), all the fresh catalysts showed the standard patterns of the 2H-MoS2 and the peaks at 2θ = 17.74 o, 33.50 o, 57.28 o belong to the (0 0 2), (1 0 0) and (1 1 0) planes of 2H-MoS2 [30]. With hydrothermal time was extended from 6 h to 24 h, these diffraction peaks became sharp, indicating the crystalline size increased and becoming more regular with hydrothermal time rise. Besides, the peak width and peak strength of (0 0 2) plane was widened and increased. To further explored the growing process during the reaction, the XRD patterns of the catalysts after 1 h,1.5 h and 20 h reaction was presented in Fig. 2(b)-(d). It was obvious that all of the peaks, especially the peaks corresponding to (0 0 2) and (1 0 0) showed a tendency of becoming sharp and highly intense, implying the particle on the catalyst became larger during reaction. Moreover, the intensity ratio of basal plane (0 0 2) to active plane (1 0 0) and the crystalline particle size of MoS2 catalysts were calculated and the results were listed in Table 1. It was clearly that the I(002/100) ratio increased with hydrothermal time, indicating the growth of active plane (1 0 0) was favorable at hydrothermal temperature 140 °C, which was consistent with our previous findings. In addition, with the increase of hydrothermal time, the intensity corresponding to basal plane (0 0 2) slightly increased that means the stacking layers increased. Since it was reported that the active site was located at the edge of MoS2 and the (0 0 2) basal plane was inert, the higher number of stacking layers meant higher activity [26,31]. 3.1.3 TEM results In order to explored the lamellar structure and stacking layers of catalysts, high resolution transmission electron microscopy was employed to investigate the morphology of the MoS2 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3 , after the reaction, all the catalysts presented multi-stacked MoS2 nanosheets and long-term ordered MoS2 stripes. With the increase of hydrothermal time, the number of stacking layers was increased (Fig. 3(a)-(d)). The average layer numbers determined from the TEM analysis are presented in Fig. S1. The Cat-6-A had 6.2 stacking layers and 8.6 layers for Cat-12-A. An increase of hydrothermal time of preparation MoS2 increased the layer number to 15.6 for Cat-24-A. The TEM result was consistent with XRD, which confirmed that with the increase of hydrothermal time, MoS2 catalyst had more stacking layers and more stable structure, which could show better catalytic stability in sulfur-resistant methanation reaction. 3.1.4 Raman spectra results XRD results demonstrated that the lamellar stacking structures of MoS2 catalysts prepared at different hydrothermal time were obviously diverse, thus we used Raman characterization technology to supplement the XRD results. As shown in Fig. 4 , different catalysts prepared at different hydrothermal times exhibited two peaks which were located at 378 cm−1 and 402 cm−1, corresponding to E 22 g g 1 and A g 1 peaks. It was reported that, the difference value of peak position between E 22 g g 1 and A g 1 was obviously related to the lamellar thickness of MoS2 catalyst [32,33]. Therefore, we indirectly evaluated the lamellar MoS2 catalysts by calculating the difference value between E 22 g g 1 and A g 1 . With the hydrothermal time increasing from 6 to 24, the difference value of E 22 g g 1 and A g 1 in Raman spectra of the four catalysts was increased from 21.4 cm−1 to 26.3 cm−1, which illustrated that through prolonging the time of hydrothermal synthesis, increasing the number of stacking layers belonged to MoS2 catalysts, which was consistent with XRD results. 3.1.5 TG and DTG analysis To investigate the carbon deposition of MoS2 catalytic methanation reaction, the TG/DTG analysis were characterized. As shown in Fig. 5 , all the samples exhibited similar tendency. And we took the Cat-24 as a typical example for analysis. From Fig. 5(a) we found that the TG curves of the intercalated samples exhibit three mass losses in the temperature range of 50–150 °C, 200–380 °C and 380–420 °C. The DTG curve was performed three endothermic peaks at 75 °C, 330 °C and 390 °C. The three peaks corresponded to the removal of water adsorbed on the catalyst surface, MoS2 oxidized to form MoO3 constantly and the process by which residual carbon species were oxidized to produce CO2 [34]. Especially for the carbon adsorbed on the catalyst surface, it would come from two kinds of sources. The one was catalysts coking during the reaction and the other was the carbon came from thiourea molecules inserted into MoS2 catalysts before reaction. Combined with Fig. 5(b), which exhibited the spent catalysts TG curves, it can be seen that the content of carbon species did not increase significantly for fresh and spent catalysts, confirming that the stability of catalysts was not mainly affected by the generation of coke. It was perhaps due to sinter at high temperature and replace of active S atoms by O atoms during methanation reaction. To further verify the deactivation of MoS2 catalysts in the reaction process, CHNS/O element analysis was carried out on the fresh and spent catalysts and the results were listed in Table 2 . As shown in Table 2, compared with the fresh catalysts, the O/S molar ratio on the spent catalysts increased significantly, which indicated that the active S atoms were replaced by O atoms during reaction. Moreover, with hydrothermal time increase, the O/S ratio decreased obviously, which revealed that longer hydrothermal time could increase the stability of the MoS2 catalysts. These results were consistent with element-mapping results shown in Fig. S2 and Fig. S3. Compared with the distribution of O element on the fresh catalyst, the O element on the spent catalyst increased significantly. In addition, the EDS results show that O content on the spent Cat-6 and Cat-24 was higher than that on the fresh catalyst, which proved that replacement of S element by O element during methanation occurred. 3.1.6 Catalytic performance The CO conversion vs time over the MoS2 catalysts obtained at different hydrothermal times were exhibited in Fig. 6 and the average statics for 20 h reaction was summarized in Table 3 . During the 20 h sulfur-resistant methanation reaction, all four catalysts had similar initial activity, but showed significant different stability with the increase of reaction time. As shown in Fig. 5, after 20 h of reaction, the CO conversion rate of catalyst Cat-24 still remained at 71.8%, and the activity remained stable, with no obvious downward trend. On the contrary, the Cat-6, Cat-12 and Cat-18 all exhibited poor reaction stability, with the initial activity decreasing from nearly 80% to 58.49%, 61.37% and 63.64%, respectively. It was revealed that with the increasing of hydrothermal time, the stability of catalyst improved gradually. The selectivity of Mo-based catalysts showed no significant difference at different hydrothermal times. Combined with the characterization results, the difference in specific surface area was not the reason for the difference in activity and stability. With the extension of hydrothermal synthesis time, the degree of crystal crystallization gradually increased, and the number of stacking layers of MoS2 also increased. Therefore, it was summarized that due to the interaction between layers, the catalyst was not easy to be sintered and deactivated at the reaction temperature, resulting in enhancing the stability of the catalyst. At the same time, the reactant molecule CO, as the provider of O atoms, gradually replaced the S atoms at the active site during the reaction process, which also affected the activity of the catalyst, and the strong intermolecular force could better hinder the substitution process which was not conducive to the activity. 3.2 Effect of solution pH value on the performance of molybdenum-based catalyst In order to verify that the number of stacking layers was a key factor for the stability of CO methanation catalyzed by MoS2, various preparation parameters was used in hydrothermal synthesis to confirm it. It was reported that, acid condition was favorable to the hydrolysis of thiourea and accelerated the nucleation rate of MoS2. When thiourea dissolved into the deionized water, H + in the solution could cause charge shielding effect at the edge of crystal, inhibiting lamellar growth and reducing accumulation [35–37]. In this section, we would control the pH value through different amounts of oxalic acid while maintaining consistency of other conditions for hydrothermal synthesis (hydrothermal temperature: 140 °C, hydrothermal time: 24 h). When oxalic acid was not added, the pH value of the precursor solution was 5.3. 3.2.1 XRD results The XRD patterns of the catalysts before and after reaction prepared at different pH values were displayed in Fig. 7 . As shown in Fig. 7(a), all the three fresh catalysts only demonstrated the characteristic peak of 2H-MoS2, indicating that the catalysts were pure MoS2 without any other impurity. Then we calculated the I(002)/(100) ratio of intensity between (0 0 2) and (1 0 0). It was found that when the solution pH value decreased from 5.3 to 0.5, the ratios were 1.26, 1.36, 1.52 and 1.33, respectively. That illustrated that the addition of oxalic acid would inhibit the lamellar growth and accumulation, making MoS2 lamellar more inclined to grow along the (1 0 0) active plane. Fig. 7(d) showed the XRD patterns of three catalysts after reaction for 20 h. Following the decrease of solution pH value, the specific diffraction peak (0 0 2) became wider and the intensity of (0 0 2) peak value increased as well as the average crystal size corresponding to (0 0 2) plane was calculated as 5.2 nm, 4.5 nm and 4.4 nm, respectively. It was demonstrated that the addition of oxalic acid could inhibited the growth of MoS2 crystal along the direction of (0 0 2) plane, resulting in the decrease of crystal particle size and the number of stacking layers, which was not conductive to the improvement of sulfur-resistant methanation stability. From Fig.7 (a)-(d), we found that the fresh catalyst generated at different pH values tend to grow and the MoS2 catalysts displayed similar rule with the catalysts from different hydrothermal times that the catalyst continued to grow and the final crystallization degree tended to be the same during reaction. 3.2.2 TEM result The high resolution transmission electron transmission electron microscopy was displayed to investigate the morphology of the obtained MoS2 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 8 and Fig. S4, when the solution value reached 5.3, the MoS2 lamellar structure was obvious dense and regular arrangement as well as a large number of stacking layers of 15.6 stacking layers, which was the reason for the excellent stability of the catalysts. However, with the excess oxalic acid added causing the solution pH achieved 0.5, the number of MoS2 stacking layers became less to 5.6, the lamellar arrangement was sparse, resulting that the catalyst contained less active edge sites on MoS2 catalysts. As H + was hydrolyzed from the solution, the electrostatic shielding effect on the MoS2 edge in the hydrothermal synthesis process inhibited the growth of the catalyst, leading to the reduction of the stacking layer number. 3.2.3 Raman spectra results As shown in Fig. S5, the catalysts prepared at different pH values exhibited two peaks which were located at 378 cm−1 and 402 cm−1, corresponding to E 22 g g 1 and A g 1 peaks. We indirectly evaluated the stacking layers of slab MoS2 by calculating the difference value between E 22 g g 1 and A g 1 . With the solution pH decreasing from 5.3 to 0.5, the difference value of E 22 g g 1 and A g 1 in Raman spectra of the three catalysts were from 26.66 cm−1 to 22.22 cm−1, which illustrated that through controlling the amount of oxalic acid to change the solution pH, decreasing the number of stacking layers. It was confirmed that through tuning solution pH value to control the number of stacking layers was successfully. And the tendency was same as XRD results. 3.2.4 TG/DTG analysis The TG/DTG curves was extensively used as the evidence to determine whether addition of oxalic acid would affect the coke and deactivation of MoS2. Compared with Fig S6(a) and Fig. S6(b), all of the three spent catalysts continued to follow a similar trend and we discussed Cat-P0.5 as an example. From curves we found that the TG curves of the intercalated samples exhibit three mass losses in the temperature range of 50–150 °C, 200–380 °C and 380–420 °C. The DTG curve was performed three endothermic peaks at 75 °C, 310 °C and 390 °C. Compared with TG results in Section 3.1.5, it was confirmed that there was no obvious coke deposition on the MoS2 catalysts during the methanation reaction. Therefore, the deactivation of catalysts perhaps attributed to the sintering at high temperature and the replacing of active S atoms by O atoms during methanation reaction. And the CHNSO element analysis was also carried out on the fresh and spent catalysts and the results were presented in Table S1. Compared with the fresh catalysts, the O/S molar ratio of the spent catalysts increased significantly, which was consistent with what we discuss in 3.1.5. Moreover, compared with the O/S molar ratio of spent catalysts, it was performed that with the increase of solution pH value inhibited the increasing of MoS2 stacking layers and stability of catalysts. While the increase of number of stacking layers for MoS2, the enhancement of interlayer interaction reduced the possibility of catalyst sintering and loss of active S, resulting in enhancing the stability of catalyst. 3.2.5 Catalytic performance As shown in Fig. 9 , After 20 h of reaction evaluation, the CO conversion rate of catalyst Cat-P5.3 still remained at 73.55%, and the activity remained stable, with no obvious downward trend. However, the Cat-P1, Cat-P3 and Cat-P0.5 exhibited poor reaction stability, with the initial activity decreasing from nearly 80% to 73.18%, 77.21% to 72.78 and from 70.00% to 64.46%, respectively. And detailed data were summarized in Table 4 . As shown in the Table 4, with the addition of oxalic acid, the methane selectivity of MoS2 catalysts decreased gradually. The above analysis results showed that the addition of appropriate amount of oxalic acid was beneficial to the initial activity of the catalyst, but not conducive to its stability. The addition of excessive oxalic acid had a negative effect on the activity and stability of the catalyst. Combined with the characterization, we clearly found that with the number of stacking layers increasing, the catalytic reaction stability was enhanced obviously. With the enhancement of the interaction force between layers, the possibility of MoS2 catalyst sintering at the reaction temperature was greatly reduced. In addition, during the reaction process, CO as the provider of O atoms replaced the S atoms at the active site, and then significantly reduced methanation activity. It was worth noting that, the Cat-P1 catalyst performed the highest initial activity but poorer stability than the catalyst without any oxalic acid added. It was generally agreed that when complex acid like citric acid or oxalic acid was added in the process of preparing MoS2 catalyst, MoS2 grew that increased S edge sites, making the original hexagonal MoS2 gradually grew towards the trend of triangle. In-situ CO adsorption followed by IR test was done to characterize the adsorption of edge sites after the addition of oxalic acid and the results were shown in Fig. S7. As reported [38,39], for MoS2 catalysts, the main band at 2112 cm−1 was determined due to the adsorption of CO, the band at 2068 cm−1on M-edge and a shoulder was recorded due to CO adsorption on S-edge of MoS2 slabs. For the catalyst prepared with oxalic acid, the ν(CO) band intensity at 2068 cm−1 on the S-edge was significantly decreased and the ν(CO) band intensity at 2112 cm−1 on the Mo-edge was obviously increased. These demonstrated that the addition of citric acid during hydrothermal synthesis would increase the amount of S-edge site while decreases the amount of M-edge site. Compared with previous DFT results on different edge sites [40], it was clear that the activity of S edge site was higher than that of Mo edge and less than S vacancy. That is why the Cat-P1 catalyst achieved the highest initial activity. Compared with Mo edge sites, S vacancy was more difficult to be formed at edge sites, which inhibited the initial activity. Besides, the catalytic activity decreased rapidly with reaction time due to the addition of oxalic acid leading to a decrease in the number of stacking layers. In summary, there exited an optimal value for the amount of oxalic acid. When oxalic acid was high, too many S-edge sites made it difficult to generate S vacancy on the activity. While when oxalic acid was low, Mo edge sites were dominant and the initial activity was low. 3.3 DFT for interlayer interactions of MoS2catalyst To further verify the relationship between the number of stacking layers and interlayers interaction, DFT calculation was used to explain this problem theoretically. Fig. 10 (a)-(c) displayed the configurations of 1 stacking layer MoS2, 2 stacking layers MoS2 and 3 stacking layers MoS2, respectively. It is clear that the distance between interlayers was 6.28 Å, which was consistent with TEM results 6.3 Å along (0 0 2) plane. Meanwhile Fig. 10(d)-(f) were electronic localization function (ELF) contours along (1 1 0) plane for different stacking layers MoS2, which indicated that the charge density of atoms in each layer enhanced with the increase of stacking layers. Furthermore, the ELF plots of electron density difference for different number of stacking layers MoS2 were shown in Fig. 10(g) and Fig. 10(h) and the orange color was corresponding to the electron acceptor. Compared with 2 stacking layers and 3 stacking layers, the orange area between layers increased, indicating that the amount of charge transfer between layers enhanced. Therefore, we deduced that with the increase of stacking layers, the charge density within the layers enhanced, which resulted in the increase of charge transfer between layers and then led to strengthening interlayer interactions. Moreover, we calculated the Bader charge to investigate the charge transfer. As shown in Table 5 , with the increase of stacking layers, the charge transfer between Mo and S atoms was enhanced, indicating that the bond energy of Mo-S bond was strengthened. 4 Conclusion A series of MoS2 catalysts were prepared by hydrothermal at 140 °C with modified hydrothermal time from 6 h to 24 h and pH values. Extending hydrothermal time has a positive effect on the stability of MoS2 catalyst for sulfur-resistant methanation reaction. A series of characterization was done and the results demonstrated that the number of stacking layers of the MoS2 was an essential factor affecting the stability. Meanwhile it was determined that during the methanation reaction, the deactivation of MoS2 was not from coke formation but from sintering and replacement of S atoms by O atoms. In addition, the effect of solution pH value during hydrothermal synthesis on the MoS2 catalyst was investigated. Lower pH value with more oxalic acid added had a negative effect on the activity and stability of the MoS2 catalyst. DFT simulation result proved that increasing the number of stacking layers of MoS2 could significantly increase the electron density of Mo and S atoms, resulting in an increase in the charge density between the layers. Then the interaction between layers was strengthened, which made the catalyst difficult to be sintered during the reaction process by preventing the replacement of S atoms by O atoms from CO. coredata.dc:description: A simple one-step hydrothermal synthesis was developed to modulate the stability of MoS2 for catalytic sulfur-resistant methanation. The methanation performance was optimized by tuning hydrothermal time and solution pH value. The catalysts were characterized by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET), X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Raman spectroscopy and thermogravimetric and derivative thermogravimetric (TG/DTG) analysis. It was found that both extended hydrothermal time and weak acidic solution value was benefit to prepare the MoS2 catalyst with high stacking layers. TG/DTG analysis indicated that no obvious coke deposition occurred in the MoS2 catalysts during methanation reaction. Moreover, density functional theory (DFT) simulation result proved that with the increase of stacking layers, the electron density between Mo atoms and their neighbor S atoms was strengthened and the interlayer interaction was enhanced. Therefore, the MoS2 catalysts with high stacking layers was stable since they were not easily deactivated by sintering or substitution of active S atoms by O atoms during the reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Enhancing stability of MoS2 catalysts for sulfur-resistant methanation by tuning interlayer interaction
